dc:description:
PIEZO1 (OMIM # 611184) was first identified as a mechanically activated cation channel in 2010 (PMID 20813920) and has been noted to be associated with autosomal dominant dehydrated hereditary stomatocytosis with or without pseudohyperkalemia and/or perinatal edema as well as autosomal recessive lymphatic malformation 6.

Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found likely differences in molecular mechanisms and therefore these disease entities have been split into separate disease entities at this time. These two disease entities do show significant phenotypic overlap and therefore, these may later be lumped together if evidence permits. The split curation of autosomal recessive lymphatic malformation 6 has been curated separately.

PIEZO1 was found to be associated with dehydrated hereditary stomatocystosis (DHS) in 2013 by Albuisson et al. DHS, also known as Hereditary Xerocytosis (HX), is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by increased permeability of erythrocyte membranes to calcium resulting in subsequent loss of potassium and dehydration. Affected individuals may show mild to moderate compensated hemolytic anemia, pseudohyperkalemia, and blood films may show occasional stomatocytes. Mechanotransduction is also a critical regulator of lymphatic vascular development, and shear stress triggers signaling pathways that promote lymphatic vessel maturation and lymphatic valve formation. Affected individuals with transient perinatal edema or fetal hydrops have been observed in DHS families for many years (PMIDs: 11001917, 23479567, 23695678, 26333996, 28716860, 29673682, 30655378, 33027564, 32109669). Numerous variants have been reported in PIEZO1 in relation to DHS, the majority being missense mutations. The proposed molecular mechanism for PIEZO1 DHS is gain of function as many of the missense variants result in slower channel inactivation or reduced threshold of activation following stimulation of patient red blood cells or cells overexpressing missense variants. However, some missense variants have been shown to have a variety of effects on protein function including response to osmotic stress, membrane trafficking, or transcript and protein stability (PMIDs: 23695678, 28716860, 33478008, 30237269, 29210095, 34737711, 33973227, 26001275, 28619848, 26001274, 30930797). Therefore, the full spectrum of molecular mechanisms has not been fully resolved at this time.

Over 50 unique variants have been reported in individuals with DHS across numerous publications and only missense variants that reach likely pathogenic status based on ACMG criteria have been counted in this curation. Many additional variants of uncertain significance in affected individuals have been reported (Figure 2 PMID 36453701). Several recurrent variants, including the most frequently reported p.Arg2456His and p.L2495_E2496dup, but also p.Val598Met, p.Ala2020Thr, p.Thr2127Met and p.Arg2488 have been noted in at least three published reports in unrelated affected individuals. Segregation in multiple unrelated families has been demonstrated in the literature (including but not limited to PMIDs 23695678, 23581886, 32109669) reaching maximum scoring for segregation.

Substantial evidence supports this gene-disease relationship including case-level data, segregation, and experimental data that supports altered protein function for a selection of variants. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts.) has been reached. In summary, there is definitive evidence to support the relationship between PIEZO1 and autosomal dominant dehydrated hereditary stomatocytosis with or without pseudohyperkalemia and/or perinatal edema. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Prenatal GCEP on the meeting date March 22nd, 2023 (SOP Version 9).

evidence.dc:description: This variant shows a gain of function.  Our GCEP has been instructed to add 0.9 to the default score of 0.1 for GOF.  Additionally, this is a variant seen in multiple unrelated affected individuals (PMIDs 30655378, 28619848, 33027564) and we have elected to upgrade this variant by 0.5 given this additional confidence in pathogenicity.
This variant shows a gain of function.  Our GCEP has been instructed to add 0.9 to the default score of 0.1 for GOF.
Functional data support gain of function - patch clamp assay, Yoda1 stimulation.  Performed in patient RBCs

This variant shows a gain of function.  Our GCEP has been instructed to add 0.9 to the default score of 0.1 for GOF.  Additionally, this is a variant seen in multiple unrelated affected individuals (PMID 30655378, 23695678, 23479567) and we have elected to upgrade this variant by 0.5 given this additional confidence in pathogenicity.
Gain of function supported by PMID 23695678 and 26001275.
This variant shows a gain of function.  Our GCEP has been instructed to add 0.9 to the default score of 0.1 for GOF.
Slower channel inactivation, consistent with gain of function

This variant shows a gain of function.  Our GCEP has been instructed to add 0.9 to the default score of 0.1 for GOF.  Additionally this variant was also reported in an unrelated affected individual in PMID 28619848.
PMID 34737711 supports gain of function
Previously scored under Picard et al 2019
Functional data supports gain of function as described in Albuisson et al 2013 and Syeda et al 2015.

This variant shows a gain of function.  Our GCEP has been instructed to add 0.9 to the default score of 0.1 for GOF.  Additionally, this is a variant seen in multiple unrelated affected individuals and we have elected to upgrade this variant by 0.5 given this additional confidence in pathogenicity.

Gain of function supported - increased sensitivity to mechanical stimulation.   Additionally GOF function support provided in Andolfo et al 2013 PMID 23479567. 
This variant has been reported in multiple unrelated affected individuals. including Grootenboer 2000 (family Arras) PMID 11001917 and Picard et al 2019 PMID 30655378.
This variant shows a gain of function.  Our GCEP has been instructed to add 0.9 to the default score of 0.1 for GOF.
PMID 33973227 supports GOF.  Additionally this variant was seen in three affected individuals from one family and in affected individual in another unrelated family (PMID: 30655378).

This variant is found in cis with p.Arg808Gln in Family 47 from Picard et al.  however, it was additionally reported in Yamaguchi et al PMID 34737711 with functional data.  Functional data shows a gain of function.  Our GCEP has been instructed to add 0.9 to the default score of 0.1 for GOF.
PMID 34737711 supports gain of function.
Sequencing panel of genes related to hemolytic anemia.
evidence.rdfs:label: Family

evidence.dc:description: Exome on the proband.  Sanger variant testing on other affected family members
evidence.rdfs:label: Family A

evidence.dc:description: Exome on proband, variant testing on the other affected family members
evidence.rdfs:label: Family 1

Additionally, this is a variant seen in multiple unrelated affected individuals and we have elected to upgrade this variant by 0.5 given this additional confidence in pathogenicity.

Functional studies support gain of function - greater sensitivity to stimulus.  Also functional data from patient cells in Aglialoro et al PMID 33478008 and Aglialoro, F. et al. PF425 PIEZO1 MEDIATED CALCIUM-INDUCED SIGNAL TRANSDUCTION IN ERYTHROBLASTS MODULATES ERYTHROPOIESIS. HemaSphere 3(S1):p 166, June 2019.

This variant shows a gain of function.  Our GCEP has been instructed to add 0.9 to the default score of 0.1 for GOF.  Additionally, this variant was seen in a homozygous state in both members of a pair of di/di twins with nonimmune fetal hydrops in Mone et al 2021 PMID 34940998
Data support gain of function - increased sensitivity to mechanical stimulus.
This variant shows a gain of function.  Our GCEP has been instructed to add 0.9 to the default score of 0.1 for GOF.
Data support gain of function as described in PMID 23695678, 23487776, 26001275
This variant shows a gain of function.  Our GCEP has been instructed to add 0.9 to the default score of 0.1 for GOF.
Delayed channel inactivation, supports gain of function

This variant shows a gain of function.  Our GCEP has been instructed to add 0.9 to the default score of 0.1 for GOF.  Additionally, this is one of the most common disease associated variants seen in multiple unrelated affected individuals and we have elected to upgrade this variant by 0.5 given this additional confidence in pathogenicity.
This is one of the most common disease associated variants.  Gain of function is supported by PMIDs 23479567,23487776,23695678, 28716860.

This variant shows a gain of function.  Our GCEP has been instructed to add 0.9 to the default score of 0.1 for GOF.  Additionally, this is a variant seen in multiple unrelated affected individuals (PMID 30655378, 23695678, 23479567, 29449963, and 29952828) and we have elected to upgrade this variant by 0.5 given this additional confidence in pathogenicity.

A different missense change of this same amnio acids was also reported in an affected individual in this paper.
This variant shows a gain of function.  Our GCEP has been instructed to add 0.9 to the default score of 0.1 for GOF.
Also reported by Albuisson 2013 (PMID 23695678). Gain of function supported by PMID 23695678 and 26001275.
Reduced score as red blood cell phenotype consistent with DHS has also been described rarely for patients with homozygous loss of function PIEZO1 variants.
Ektacytometry determined that patient red blood cells had increased H2O volume, reduced K+, increased Na+ consistent with increased channel activity.
evidence.rdfs:label: Ektacytometry of patient RBCs

evidence.dc:description: G782S either alone or as double mutation G782S/R808Q showed an increased peak current consistent with a gain of function phenotype.
evidence.rdfs:label: HEK/239T Stretch-activated current assay

evidence.dc:description: Upon mechanical stimulation cells with Piezo1 had increased calcium release determined by calcium imaging which is consistent with increased channel activity.
evidence.rdfs:label: Calcium imaging and mechanical stimulation

evidence.dc:description: Two additional papers (PMID:28716860, doi.org/10.1182/blood.V124.21.741.741) showed similar results.
Expression of mutations was associated with slow inactivation kinetics.
evidence.rdfs:label: Patch clamp of HEK/293T cells

evidence.dc:description: Additional paper replicates the same result PMID: 30482854
Lymphatic dysfunction due to lack of responses to flow.
evidence.rdfs:label: Down steam gene induction

evidence.dc:description: Both loss of function and gain of function of PIEZO1 is associated with DHS.
evidence.rdfs:label: YODA stimulation of Red Blood Cell

evidence.dc:description: Demonstrate expression in murine red blood cells
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression analysis
